transcripts.text: Withdrawal agreement was just simply a legal text that took us into a transition period in order to negotiate a deal.  Yeah, but that's when the negotiations start on the future trading relationship.  Those negotiations haven't begun.  Once you agree a withdrawal agreement, those negotiations begin.  Well, there isn't a deal.  That's what I'm trying to explain to you.
It's news to me.  You're now rewriting history.  I'm not rewriting history.  I've now heard everything.
I'm not rewriting history.  It's just nonsense.
You're telling me that the withdrawal agreement...

You don't seem to understand what the withdrawal agreement is.  The withdrawal agreement, which I have read, is 585 pages of legal text which settles a series of questions about security, data sharing protocols, the divorce bill, and ushers in a transition period in which you start to negotiate Britain's future trading relationship with the EU.

Well, I think everybody knows, right, that whether or not you leave with a deal or without a deal, you have to negotiate quite a lot for quite some years to come.  And that will always be the case.  And Parliament had no right to any say over those negotiations.  This is why people are feeling as though they've been misled.  because you're using parliamentary procedures and parliamentary niceties and parliamentary language to basically get away from the point which is either you want to leave the European Union or you do not.  And now we've got Labour MPs saying, oh, we wish we voted for Theresa May's deal now, and now we'd like to.  We didn't have that vote.
I'm sorry, I'm not saying that.  I've never said that.
I don't know where you're getting this from.  You're the only person sitting in this entire area who thinks you didn't vote down Theresa May's withdrawal agreement.

The withdrawal agreement bill was proposed to Parliament.  We never got a vote on it.  And that is one of the reasons why Stephen Kinnock and others this week are trying to bring back the withdrawal agreement bill to give Parliament the chance to vote for that for the first time.  Theresa May told us she had a withdrawal agreement bill that she was planning to bring before Parliament.

Ruth Smeeth was on TV last night saying that she regretted voting against Theresa May's withdrawal agreement and would now like to vote for it.  So you're telling me that nobody's ever voted for it at all?

We had three meaningful votes.  That is not a withdrawal agreement bill.  The withdrawal agreement bill never came before Parliament.  We're trying to bring it before Parliament this week so that we can actually vote for it.  And with respect, if I could say this... You say that Labour MPs are sitting here trying to use misleading language in order to mislead the public.  You keep talking about a deal.  We haven't negotiated a deal.  And this is part of what is obscuring this for the public.  You have to be clear about what's happened here.  And you're not having the trust.
Well, you're going to tell me.  Well, I am telling the truth, because that's what I do.  What I don't do is obfuscate the truth, which is what you people do.
That's what you've just done.  That's exactly what you've just done.

So you're telling me that Theresa May did not go to Brussels.  We're telling the public we've got a deal.  We haven't started negotiating a deal.  You're telling me Theresa May did not go to Brussels, did not negotiate a deal, did not bring it before Parliament, and it was not voted on.

She negotiated a withdrawal agreement which settled legal and technical questions and allowed the UK then to go and negotiate a deal.  Those negotiations haven't yet started.  That is one of the reasons the public are so frustrated, it's one of the reasons I'm so frustrated and it's one of the reasons that we're trying to bring that withdrawal agreement bill before Parliament for the first time to see if we can get a majority for it and then allow Parliament and the government to have a role and a say in what those future trade and relationship arrangements look
like.  Why don't you have an election?  then you can be in charge of the government And then you could do what you wanted.

Because if we have an election right now, we give Boris Johnson the power to set the date.  And if he sets the date for after the 31st of October, we leave the EU with no deal and no arrangements at all.
Well, you say we haven't got a deal now.
We've got a deal.
You just told me we didn't have a deal.
We haven't left the EU yet.  So we've got a deal.  in that we're still technically members of the European Union.  You just told me we haven't got a deal.
We can't even have a deal a minute ago and now not have a deal.
I think you're just trying to be difficult, to be honest.
I'm not.  I'm just trying to get at the truth.
I'm just trying to get at the truth.  We haven't left the EU yet.
Right, so do we have a deal?

We haven't negotiated a deal, no.  You just said we had a deal.  But we're in the EU at the moment.  Yes.  If we leave on the 31st of October, we aren't... I don't really understand what's so difficult about this for you.
Well, it's not for me that's difficult.  I do my job every day, right?  You guys haven't done your job for three years.
Well, this is just complete nonsense because you're not doing your job now.  You're pretending to the public that all we're doing in Parliament is running around trying to stop a deal.

And that's what they'd say to me.  Because I talk to the public every single day and that's what they say to me.  They're sick to death of politicians arguing over semantics, arguing over little niceties and making excuses about why we cannot do what they asked you to do, which is to leave the European Union.
And frankly, with media commentary of this level, I'm not surprised that they're confused and upset about what's going on.
Oh, so you think it's our fault now?
I think you're not shedding any light on this process at all.
I'm trying to get at the truth.  So far you've told me three different versions of it.
No, it's nonsense.  All you're creating is heat rather than light.  Is that right?  And actually, frankly, at the moment, that's quite shameful.

What we're doing today... I think what you're doing is quite shameful as well, but I wouldn't say that to you because I have great respect for the parliamentarians behind me here who are supposed to be voted in.  to do the bidding of the people who voted you in.
You've just spent five minutes saying that we're not doing our jobs and we're letting the country vote.  Well, you're not, are you?  And talking absolute nonsense, frankly.
